FAQ.title: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.subtitle: Everything you need to know about tech mentoring

questions.question: What does a tech career mentor do?
questions.answer: A tech career mentor accompanies you to design your career plan in technology. We work together on: clarifying your next step (first job, promotion, transition), developing skills that AI can't replace (leadership, strategic communication), overcoming impostor syndrome, avoiding burnout and building a sustainable career with purpose. I don't just give advice, I help you discover your strengths and make decisions aligned with your values.

questions.question: How does HugoTech help prevent programmer burnout?
questions.answer: Burnout in tech is real and silent. We work on: identifying the 7 signs of burnout before it's too late, creating healthy digital boundaries (Slack, email, meetings), designing your 30-day anti-burnout plan, protecting your recharge time without guilt, and deciding if your exhaustion is recoverable or if you need to change environments. My approach is preventive: building a tech career where success doesn't drain you from the inside.

questions.question: How much does a tech coaching session cost in Peru?
questions.answer: The first session is completely free, no strings attached. It's a 45-minute session to get to know each other and evaluate if my guidance serves you. If you decide to continue, follow-up sessions work by voluntary donation (suggested: S/35 soles, ~$10 USD). 100% of what's collected is donated to social causes in Peru: animal shelters, tech scholarships for young people and community kitchens. <link>See social causes</link>. Your investment in yourself also helps others.

questions.question: Is mentoring only for junior developers or also for seniors?
questions.answer: I work with the entire tech career spectrum: Juniors and Career Switchers (first job, fundamentals, impostor syndrome), Mid-Level Developers (next step, specialization vs generalization), Seniors and Tech Leads (transition to Manager, Staff Engineer or Entrepreneur, leadership without burnout), and Introverted tech professionals (leading without faking extroversion). Each profile has unique challenges and we design a personalized plan according to your career moment.

questions.question: Are sessions online or in-person?
questions.answer: All sessions are online (Zoom, Google Meet or the platform you prefer). This allows schedule flexibility and eliminates geographical barriers. I serve developers from Peru, Mexico, Colombia, Chile, Argentina, United States and other Latin American countries. Sessions can be in Spanish or English according to your preference.

cta.text: Have more questions? Let's talk in your free session.

hero.title: I was also <highlight>searching for my north star</highlight>
hero.subtitle: 18+ years building tech, teams and conscious leaders
hero.description: Today I know that talent without purpose is potential without direction. And that the best transformations begin with a single honest conversation.

purpose.title: What I learned along the way
purpose.quote: Purpose doesn't appear in a dashboard. It's discovered in honest conversations.
purpose.intro: At 40 years old, after necessary pauses and uncomfortable questions, I understood something: I wasn't alone. There were thousands of tech professionals feeling the same. Talented in code, searching for purpose.
purpose.conclusion: That's where my north star was born: Be authentic (no corporate poses), accompany those who come behind, and build with soul where the human matters as much as the code.
purpose.mission: I don't want you to wait years to ask the important questions. Today I accompany tech professionals to find their path with clarity and purpose. Because the best technology is built by people who know themselves.

journey.title: My Path: From Code to People

phases.title: From code to conversations
content: I started writing code at 3am, passionate about finding the perfect solution. PHP, MySQL, complex architectures... I always moved forward: from full-stack development to technical leadership, from Product Owner to transforming complete organizational cultures.
I never stopped. But along the way I discovered something more powerful than the perfect framework: the impact of accompanying tech people to find their purpose.

Today I no longer code in PHP or JavaScript, but I'm still the same committed innovator. Only now my code is conversations that transform teams, my deployment is helping leaders grow, and my best architecture is building cultures where people flourish.

phases.title: Real challenges aren't in the code
content: As a Tech Lead I discovered something: the best code doesn't transform if the person writing it doesn't feel connected.
Talented developers without spaces to grow. Product Owners without vision clarity. Teams without real conversations.
That's where my search began: I studied coaching, agility, facilitation, conscious leadership.
I became certified in ICF Coaching, Management 3.0, Scrum, Lean... seeking answers beyond code.

phases.title: When success isn't enough
content: At 35, I stopped. I was leading teams, important projects, recognition... but something was missing.
Nights asking myself: Am I building what really matters?
That pause was uncomfortable and necessary. It led me to professional coaching, honest conversations, to ask myself who I was without the title.
I discovered that many share this feeling. That understanding became my starting point.

phases.title: From technology to people
content: I worked 18+ years in tech (Peru, LATAM, U.S.). I led digital transformations, agile teams, scalable products.
But what gave me the most meaning were the mentoring conversations with someone seeking their path.
Seeing someone connect with their purpose in a session was worth more than any technical milestone.
Every time someone said "this conversation gave me clarity", I felt I was contributing something real.

phases.title: HugoTech: sharing what I've learned
content: HugoTech was born from a question: How to accompany without money being an obstacle?
I decided that 1-to-1 sessions would be 100% free. Not as a strategy, but as a commitment.
If today I can accompany someone, it's because others did the same for me at key moments.
This space is my way of giving back what I received and building with purpose.

evolution.title: 18+ years transforming (and being transformed)
evolution.subtitle: From writing my first line of code to leading cultural transformations in high-performance teams

phases.title: Backend Developer ‚Üí Love for architecture
phases.description: I started with PHP, MySQL, MVC architectures. I built systems from scratch: e-commerce platforms, ERPs, ticketing systems for transportation. I learned that clean code isn't just syntax, it's empathy with whoever comes after.

phases.title: Frontend Developer ‚Üí Experience matters (and I'm passionate about it)
phases.description: I discovered that the interface is where users feel the product. JavaScript, React, animations, performance, accessibility. It wasn't enough for it to work, it had to feel good, flow, excite. UX became my obsession: understanding every click, every microinteraction, every loading second. I fell in love with creating experiences people love to use.

phases.title: Full Stack Developer ‚Üí See the complete picture + Growth
phases.description: I brought both worlds together: backend architecture + frontend experience. Now I could see the complete product, understand trade-offs, make technical decisions thinking about the business. But it wasn't enough to build well: I discovered my passion for digital marketing and growth. Analytics, conversion, funnels, A/B testing. Every line of code was an opportunity to grow the business.

phases.title: Tech Lead & Product Owner ‚Üí Code isn't enough
phases.description: I led teams, defined roadmaps, negotiated with stakeholders. But here I discovered the truth: the best products are born from aligned and motivated teams. Perfect code wasn't enough if people didn't have clarity, purpose or spaces to grow.

phases.title: Country Manager ‚Üí Data-Driven culture and strategic vision
phases.description: I managed operations in Peru coordinating development, marketing, call center, sales and talent management teams. I learned that success isn't just in the product, but in aligning multiple areas toward a common goal, measuring impact with KPIs and OKRs. I became obsessed with building a data-driven culture: every decision backed by data, every strategy validated with metrics. I understood that people are the most powerful strategy, and data is their best ally.

phases.title: Digital Strategist & Agile Coach ‚Üí Transform people and cultures
phases.description: Today my code is conversations that transform teams. My deployment is helping leaders find their voice. My best architecture is building cultures where people flourish and talent becomes real impact. I no longer code in JavaScript, but I keep innovating: now in human development.

evolution.quote: From backend code to leading countries. From managing KPIs to transforming cultures. I'm still an innovator, only now my language is people.

hero.title: Have questions? Here are the answers
hero.subtitle: Everything you need to know about tech mentoring with purpose, free sessions, and how to start your transformation

por-que-senior-necesita-mentor.question: Why does a Senior Developer need a technical mentor?
por-que-senior-necesita-mentor.answer: A Senior Developer needs a technical mentor because professional growth doesn't end when you reach Senior level. The challenges change: it's no longer just about writing code, but leading architectures, mentoring juniors, communicating technical decisions to stakeholders, and navigating organizational politics. A technical mentor helps you see your blind spots, make strategic career decisions (Staff Engineer or Engineering Manager?), develop leadership skills without losing technical essence, and avoid the stagnation that affects 67% of seniors after 3 years in the same role.

como-ayuda-mentor-burnout.question: How does a tech mentor help prevent developer burnout?
como-ayuda-mentor-burnout.answer: A tech mentor helps prevent burnout by identifying early signs like chronic fatigue, cynicism towards work, and loss of productivity. They teach you to establish healthy boundaries between work and personal life, communicate your workload assertively, recognize when a project or culture is toxic, and develop sustainable self-care strategies. Additionally, they help you reconnect with your professional purpose when you feel your work has no impact. Tech burnout isn't solved just with vacation: it's prevented with mindset, boundaries, and a mentor who understands industry pressure because they lived it.

diferencia-mentor-coach-tech.question: What's the difference between a technical mentor and an executive coach?
diferencia-mentor-coach-tech.answer: A technical mentor has direct experience in technology (development, architecture, leading tech teams) and shares industry-specific knowledge. They guide you with real examples from their career, connect you with their professional network, and give you validated shortcuts to grow in tech. An executive coach focuses on general soft skills (leadership, communication, time management) without necessarily understanding the specific technical challenges of a developer: impostor syndrome in code reviews, anxiety about being technologically outdated, or how to lead distributed remote teams. A technical mentor combines both worlds: technical expertise + human development.

habilidades-ia-no-reemplaza.question: What human skills can AI not replace in developers?
habilidades-ia-no-reemplaza.answer: AI can generate code, but it cannot replace critical human skills in developers: empathetic communication with stakeholders to understand real needs beyond what they say, technical leadership that inspires and motivates distributed teams, architectural decision-making considering political and business factors, conflict management in code reviews without damaging relationships, creativity to solve ambiguous problems without clear specifications, mentorship that transforms juniors into seniors sustainably, and trust-building in teams that enables innovation without fear of failure. In 2025, the most valuable developers are those who combine technical expertise with emotional intelligence, systems thinking, and the ability to influence without formal authority.

sintomas-estancamiento-senior.question: What are the symptoms of stagnation in a Senior Developer?
sintomas-estancamiento-senior.answer: Symptoms of stagnation in a Senior Developer include: doing the same type of tasks repetitively without learning anything new, feeling your work is 'more of the same' without technical challenges, not receiving constructive feedback or promotions for more than 2 years, avoiding learning new technologies due to lack of motivation, intensified impostor syndrome ('I never know enough'), loss of passion for technology that used to excite you, and constantly questioning whether you should change companies, tech stack, or even careers. Stagnation isn't lack of talent: it's lack of clear direction and challenges that stretch you professionally.

cuando-buscar-mentor-tech.question: When is the right time to seek a technical mentor?
cuando-buscar-mentor-tech.answer: The right time to seek a technical mentor is when you feel your growth has stalled, when you're in a career transition (from developer to tech lead, from backend to fullstack, from IC to management), when suffering from burnout or paralyzing impostor syndrome, when you rejected or accepted a job offer and now have doubts, when your company lacks seniors to learn from, or when you want to jump to Senior/Staff but don't know how. It's also critical to seek mentorship before making important decisions: changing companies, negotiating salary, choosing between two offers, or deciding whether to specialize or remain a generalist. A mentor saves you years of costly mistakes.

que-esperar-primera-sesion-mentor.question: What can I expect from my first session with a technical mentor?
que-esperar-primera-sesion-mentor.answer: In your first session with a technical mentor you can expect an honest 45-60 minute conversation where we explore your current situation (career, challenges, goals), identify your strengths and blind spots you don't see alone, define your immediate objective (next 3-6 months), and design an initial action plan with concrete steps. It's not empty motivational talk: it's real diagnosis + applicable strategy. A good mentor asks uncomfortable questions that force you to reflect, gives you perspectives you hadn't considered, and challenges you to leave your comfort zone. If by the end you don't feel clarity or connection, that mentor isn't for you. The first session should leave you with renewed energy and clear direction.

como-prepararse-para-tech-lead.question: How can a mentor help me prepare to be a Tech Lead?
como-prepararse-para-tech-lead.answer: A mentor helps you prepare to be a Tech Lead by developing skills you don't learn from programming: delegating without micromanaging, giving technical feedback without destroying team trust, negotiating realistic deadlines with product managers, communicating architectural decisions to non-technical stakeholders, effectively mentoring junior developers, handling difficult conversations (underperformance, conflicts), and balancing time between code and leadership. They share real experiences from their transition to Tech Lead, help you identify if leadership is your path or if you prefer the Staff/Principal Engineer route, and prepare you for the first 90 days in the role where 40% of new Tech Leads fail due to lack of clarity in their new professional identity.

mentor-para-primer-empleo-tech.question: Can a mentor help me get my first tech job?
mentor-para-primer-empleo-tech.answer: Yes, a tech mentor can accelerate your process to get your first job by teaching you to build a portfolio that demonstrates real skills (not just copied tutorials), prepare for technical interviews with algorithm and system design problems, develop communication skills to explain your code clearly, understand what recruiters look for in a junior (learning attitude, collaboration, autonomy), and connect you with their professional network for referrals (70% of tech jobs come from networking, not cold applications). They also help you manage emotional rejection from failed interviews, identify red flags in job offers, and negotiate your first salary without selling yourself cheap out of desperation.

mentor-remoto-vs-presencial.question: Is 100% remote technical mentoring effective?
mentor-remoto-vs-presencial.answer: Yes, 100% remote technical mentoring is equally effective (sometimes more) than in-person because current tools (Zoom, Google Meet, VS Code Live Share, Miro, Notion) enable high-quality sessions with screen sharing, virtual pair programming, and collaborative documentation. Remote advantages include: schedule flexibility (ideal for different time zones), session recording for later review, access to international mentors with experience in USA/Europe companies you wouldn't have locally, elimination of commute time, and greater comfort discussing vulnerable topics (impostor syndrome, burnout, insecurities) from your safe space. 85% of tech mentoring post-2020 is remote and shows satisfaction rates similar to or higher than in-person.

mentoring-gratis.question: Are the mentoring sessions really free?
mentoring-gratis.answer: Yes, 1-on-1 sessions are 100% free. No fine print, no hidden agenda. It's my way of giving back to the world what life gave me. I want money not to be a barrier to your professional growth. If you want structured coaching afterwards, there's <link href='/coaching-con-causa'>Coaching with Purpose</link>.

coaching-con-causa.question: What is Coaching with Purpose?
coaching-con-causa.answer: It's an option where your first session is free. If you decide to continue, each session costs S/35 soles (~USD $10) that goes 100% to social causes: animal shelters, tech scholarships, education, reforestation. Your growth helps the world. <link href='/coaching-con-causa'>See real-time impact here</link>.

diferencia-coaching-mentoring.question: What's the difference between Coaching and Mentor Coaching?
diferencia-coaching-mentoring.answer: 1-on-1 Coaching focuses on BEING: self-knowledge, purpose, personal balance. Mentor Coaching focuses on DOING: your tech career, leadership skills, next professional steps. Both combine human development with strategy.

primera-sesion.question: What happens in the first session?
primera-sesion.answer: It's an honest 45-minute conversation to get to know each other. We explore what you're looking for, what's holding you back, where you want to go. If by the end you feel we don't connect, that's okay. No commitment, no pressure.

sesiones-empresas.question: Do you offer corporate programs?
sesiones-empresas.answer: Yes. I work with tech teams through agile leadership workshops, executive coaching, organizational culture programs and high-performance team transformation. B2B services have an investment because they require structure, follow-up and measurable results.

modalidad.question: Are sessions in-person or online?
modalidad.answer: 100% online, via Google Meet or Zoom. This allows us to connect no matter where you are: Peru, Latin America, Europe, USA. You just need stable internet and a quiet space for the session.

duracion-sesion.question: How long does each session last?
duracion-sesion.answer: Each session lasts 45 minutes. It's enough time to delve into a specific topic, explore new perspectives and design concrete action steps. If you need more time, we can coordinate it.

temas-trabajamos.question: What topics can be worked on in sessions?
temas-trabajamos.answer: Self-knowledge, professional purpose, impostor syndrome, effective communication, leadership, burnout, career transition, decision making, emotional management, confidence, soft skills, tech roadmap, work-life balance.

quien-puede-solicitar.question: Who can request a session?
quien-puede-solicitar.answer: Anyone in tech: developers, QA, designers, product owners, scrum masters, tech leads, tech students, professionals in transition. If you work in technology or want to enter the sector, this is for you. Read <link href='/testimonials'>real stories from people who lived it</link>.

como-agendar.question: How do I schedule my session?
como-agendar.answer: Easy: click 'Schedule your free session', choose the day and time that works best for you on Calendly, fill out a brief form to focus the session, and that's it. You'll receive a confirmation email with the video call link.

que-es-coaching-desde-mi-perspectiva.question: What is coaching from your perspective, Hugo?
que-es-coaching-desde-mi-perspectiva.answer: For me, coaching is a safe space where you allow yourself to be vulnerable. It's not someone telling you what to do, but someone who asks you the questions you avoid asking yourself. After <link href='/about'>10 years leading tech teams</link>, living through burnout, impostor syndrome, and difficult transitions, I learned that the biggest obstacle is not technical‚Äîit's the limiting beliefs we repeat to ourselves. Coaching is that conversation where you finally give yourself permission to think differently. It's not magic, nor quick fixes. It's a process of deep self-awareness that transforms how you see yourself, your career, and your decisions. My style combines the structure of a tech mentor (I've been where you are: sprints, code reviews, complex architectures) with the empathy of someone who understands that behind every senior developer is a human being with doubts, fears, and dreams. I'm not here to give you recipes, but to challenge you, accompany you, and celebrate your growth. Learn more about <link href='/about'>my story and philosophy</link>.

que-es-mentor-coach.question: What is a mentor coach?
que-es-mentor-coach.answer: A mentor coach is a professional who combines two roles: MENTOR: Shares direct experience. 'I've been in your situation before, here's what I learned, here are the patterns I see.' Gives advice based on their career path, shows shortcuts, helps avoid mistakes they made. COACH: Doesn't impose answers, asks powerful questions so YOU discover your solutions. Works on mindset, limiting beliefs, self-awareness, decision-making. The difference from a traditional mentor: a mentor coach doesn't just say 'do this', but helps you think for yourself. For example: MENTOR: 'When I became Tech Lead, I implemented daily standups and structured 1-on-1s.' MENTOR COACH: 'What does being a Tech Lead mean to you? What leadership style aligns with your values? What's stopping you from being the leader you want to be?' It combines the wisdom of experience (mentor) with the transformative power of coaching questions (coach). I'm a mentor coach because I share my 10 years in tech, but I don't impose my path on you: I help you design yours. Learn about <link href='/metodo-hugotech'>my working methodology here</link>.

que-es-mentor-coach-tech.question: What is a tech mentor coach?
que-es-mentor-coach-tech.answer: A tech mentor coach is a mentor coach specialized in technology professionals (developers, QA, tech leads, product managers). The key: understands your reality because they lived it‚Äîendless sprints, impostor syndrome when reviewing code from others, pressure to stay updated with frameworks, anxiety of oncall, frustration of technical debt, loneliness of remote work, difficult decisions between technical growth and management. It's not generic executive coaching that doesn't understand your jargon. A tech mentor coach speaks your language: understands what a sprint retrospective is, why microservices complicate your life, what it means to migrate a monolith, what you feel when your PR is destroyed in code review, the dilemma of staying Senior IC or becoming Engineering Manager. Combines technical mentoring (career, architecture, technical decisions) with coaching on human skills (communication, leadership, confidence, work-life balance, purpose). I'm a mentor coach tech because I built products from scratch, led distributed teams, made bad technical decisions, lived burnout, overcame impostor syndrome. I don't advise from theory: I accompany you from lived experience. Read <link href='/testimonials'>real transformation stories</link> from other tech professionals.

que-es-coaching-tech.question: What is tech coaching?
que-es-coaching-tech.answer: Tech coaching is professional coaching applied to technology sector professionals. It's NOT teaching you to program, nor technical mentoring on architecture. It's working on the human and strategic part of your tech career: developing soft skills (communication, influence, difficult conversations), overcoming impostor syndrome ('I'm not good enough to be senior'), preventing and managing burnout (sprints without end, always-on culture), facilitating transitions (IC to Manager, Backend to Fullstack, employee to freelance), improving your tech personal brand (LinkedIn, talks, visibility), negotiating salary and promotions based on impact, designing your medium and long-term career path, building confidence to lead technical initiatives and teams. The difference from generic coaching: a tech coach understands your context‚Äîyour challenges are not the same as a sales executive or a lawyer. In tech you face unique pressure: constant obsolescence, meritocracy culture, remote work, cross-cultural teams, Stack Overflow as judge of your value. Tech coaching helps you not just survive in tech, but thrive with purpose, balance, and confidence. Check <link href='/pricing'>investment options with purpose</link>.

para-que-sirve-coaching-vida.question: What is coaching for in everyday life?
para-que-sirve-coaching-vida.answer: Coaching serves to live consciously instead of reacting automatically. In everyday life, coaching helps you: CLARITY: Understand what you really want (not what others expect from you). Define your priorities, values, and purpose. DECISIONS: Make important choices from self-knowledge, not from fear, guilt, or external pressure. Career change? Ask for a raise? End a relationship? Coaching gives you tools to decide with confidence. RELATIONSHIPS: Improve how you communicate with your partner, family, bosses, coworkers. Set healthy boundaries without guilt. SELF-CONFIDENCE: Overcome impostor syndrome, self-sabotage, limiting beliefs ('I'm not good enough', 'I don't deserve success'). BALANCE: Find work-life balance, avoid burnout, learn to say no, prioritize your mental health. ACTION: Stop procrastinating, design concrete plans, maintain commitment to your goals, celebrate small progress. It's not therapy (doesn't resolve traumas), nor consultancy (doesn't tell you what to do). Coaching is that space where you stop, reflect, and design the life you want to live. Not the one you inherited or the one others chose for you. It's an investment in yourself that transforms everything. Discover <link href='/coaching-con-causa'>the social impact investment model</link>.

que-es-coaching-tecnologico.question: What is tech coaching?
que-es-coaching-tecnologico.answer: Tech coaching is a specialized professional development process for people in the tech sector (developers, QA, tech leads, product managers). It combines traditional coaching (self-awareness, emotional management, decision-making) with tech industry expertise: tech career transitions, dev team leadership, impostor syndrome in programmers, startup burnout, tech salary negotiation, and tech stack decisions. Unlike generic executive coaching, tech coaches understand the jargon, culture, and unique challenges of working in technology: sprints, code reviews, oncall, deployments, software architecture, and the constant pressure to stay updated. It's mentoring + coaching applied to the tech world.

cuales-son-4-pilares-coaching.question: What are the 4 pillars of coaching?
cuales-son-4-pilares-coaching.answer: The 4 fundamental pillars of coaching are: 1) TRUST - Foundation of the process. Without trust (sincerity, coach competence), there is no openness or vulnerability. The coachee must feel safe to share fears, doubts, failures. 2) AWARENESS - Deep self-knowledge. Coaching helps the coachee realize their thought patterns, limiting beliefs, hidden strengths, and blind spots that block their growth. 3) AUTHENTIC COMMUNICATION - Active listening and powerful questions. The coach doesn't advise, asks questions that challenge the coachee to think differently. Empathy without judgment. 4) ACTION/ACCOUNTABILITY - Design of concrete steps and coachee commitment to their process. Coaching is not reflective therapy: it generates real and measurable changes in professional and personal life.

que-hace-coach-tecnico.question: What does a tech coach do?
que-hace-coach-tecnico.answer: A tech coach helps technology sector professionals grow in their career and develop critical human skills. Their functions include: identifying technical and soft skills gaps, creating personalized career plans (Senior? Tech Lead? Change stack?), preparing for technical interviews and salary negotiation, developing communication skills (technical presentations, influence without authority), working on impostor syndrome and self-confidence, preventing and managing tech burnout, facilitating transitions (IC to Manager, Backend to Fullstack), mentoring on software architecture and strategic technical decisions, and helping build tech personal brand (LinkedIn, conferences, blogs). Doesn't write code for you, but helps you think better, communicate better, and make career decisions aligned with your purpose.

cuales-son-3-c-coaching.question: What are the 3 C's of coaching?
cuales-son-3-c-coaching.answer: The 3 C's of exceptional coaching are: 1) CURIOSITY - Foundation of a good coach. Genuine curiosity to understand the coachee beyond the superficial. Not assume, but ask. Not judge, but explore. The coach's curiosity generates deep reflection in the coachee. 2) COURAGE - Courage to ask the difficult questions no one else asks. Courage to confront with empathy the coachee's contradictions. Courage to hold uncomfortable silences that generate powerful insights. Courage to challenge the coachee to leave their comfort zone. 3) COMPASSION - Deep empathy without becoming a rescuer. Compassion to accompany the pain of the change process, but without taking away the coachee's responsibility for their transformation. Compassion to celebrate each small advance. A coach with the 3 C's transforms lives, not just careers.

4-etapas-coaching.question: What are the 4 stages of coaching?
4-etapas-coaching.answer: The coaching process has 4 key stages: 1) REACTION/EXPLORATION - First phase where the coachee arrives with a problem, pain, confusion. Initial exploration of the current situation, identification of emotions, and building coach-coachee trust. 2) LEARNING/AWARENESS - Phase of deep self-knowledge. The coachee becomes aware of their limiting patterns, beliefs, hidden strengths. Paradigms are questioned. Here the greatest insights occur: 'I didn't know I thought that way'. 3) BEHAVIOR/EXPERIMENTATION - Design of new actions aligned with insights. The coachee experiments with new behaviors in their real life: new conversations, different decisions, healthy boundaries. What works and what doesn't is measured. 4) RESULTS/INTEGRATION - Consolidation of changes. The coachee integrates learnings as part of their new identity. Results are visible: promotion, better communication, work-life balance, confidence. Coaching ends when the coachee no longer needs the coach.

cuanto-cobra-coach-peru.question: How much does a coach charge in Peru?
cuanto-cobra-coach-peru.answer: The cost of coaching in Peru varies by experience, certification and niche: General Coaches (without certification): S/50-150 soles per session. ICF Certified Coaches (Associate/Professional): S/200-400 soles per session. Specialized Coaches (Executive, Tech, Life Coaching): S/300-600 soles per session. Coaching Programs (4-6 sessions): S/800-2,500 soles. Corporate B2B Coaching: S/1,000-3,000 soles per session + annual programs. In my case, my model is different: 1-to-1 Tech Mentoring Sessions are 100% FREE. Coaching with Purpose: first session free, following S/35 going 100% to social causes. My philosophy is that money should not be a barrier to your professional growth. B2B services (companies) do have investment because they require structure and measurable results.

3-pilares-coaching.question: What are the 3 pillars of coaching?
3-pilares-coaching.answer: The 3 essential pillars of effective coaching are: 1) AWARENESS - The foundation of all change. The coachee becomes aware of their thoughts, emotions, limiting beliefs, and behavior patterns that sabotage their success. Without awareness, there is no transformation. 2) SELF-BELIEF/ACCOUNTABILITY - The coachee assumes total responsibility for their life and decisions. Stops victimizing themselves, blaming others, or waiting for circumstances to change. Believes in their ability to create their own future. 3) ACTION/COMMITMENT - Coaching is not just reflective conversation: it generates concrete and measurable actions. The coachee designs specific steps, experiments with new behaviors, measures results, and adjusts strategy. Without action, coaching is endless therapy. These 3 pillars work together: awareness generates responsibility, responsibility generates action, and action generates results that reinforce awareness.

diferencia-entrenador-manager.question: What's the difference between a coach and a manager?
diferencia-entrenador-manager.answer: The key difference between a coach and a manager is: COACH: No formal authority over you. Doesn't tell you what to do. Asks powerful questions for you to discover your own answers. Their success is measured by YOUR growth, not business objectives. Confidential relationship, no corporate agenda. Challenges you without judging. Their goal is to expand your awareness and decision-making capacity. MANAGER: Has formal authority (can promote or fire you). Must meet business objectives (delivery, roadmap, KPIs). Their success depends on team performance. Gives directives when necessary. Evaluates your performance with metrics. Professional relationship with clear limits. A good manager can have coaching skills (empower, ask, develop), but their main role is management. A coach is never your boss: they're your mirror, your challenger, and your ally in your own growth.

que-estudiar-ser-coach.question: What should I study to be a coach?
que-estudiar-ser-coach.answer: To be a professional coach you need: 1) ICF Certification (International Coaching Federation) - The global standard. Levels: ACC (Associate, 60 hrs), PCC (Professional, 125 hrs), MCC (Master, 200 hrs). ICF accredited programs: Newfield Network (Ontological), Coaching Academy, CTI, etc. 2) Training in Positive Psychology, NLP (Neuro-Linguistic Programming), or Emotional Intelligence. 3) Specialization in a niche: Executive Coaching, Career Coaching, Life Coaching, Tech Coaching, etc. 4) Practice hours: ICF requires 100-500 hours of supervised coaching. 5) Supervision and Mentoring with experienced coaches. 6) Continuous Personal Development: your best tool is your own transformation. IMPORTANT: In Peru anyone can call themselves a coach (not regulated), but ICF certification is your professional differentiator and ethical validation. You'll invest between S/5,000-25,000 soles and 6-12 months in serious certification.

cuanto-cuesta-sesion-coaching-peru.question: How much does a coaching session cost in Peru?
cuanto-cuesta-sesion-coaching-peru.answer: The average cost of a coaching session in Peru (Lima, 2025) is: General Coaching (without certification): S/80-150 per 60 min session. ICF Certified Coaching: S/200-400 per session. Specialized Coaching (Executive, Tech, Leadership): S/300-600 per session. 4-6 session packages: S/800-2,000 with discount. Group Coaching/Workshops: S/50-120 per person. Corporate Coaching (B2B): S/1,500-3,500 per executive (3-6 month program). My model is different by conviction: 1-to-1 Tech Mentoring: 100% FREE, no strings attached. Coaching with Purpose: First session free. Following: S/35 going 100% to social causes (animal shelters, tech scholarships, community kitchens). My philosophy: Professional growth should not be limited by economic resources. If you have the commitment, I provide the experience.

cuantos-anos-carrera-coach.question: How many years is a coaching career?
cuantos-anos-carrera-coach.answer: There is no 'coaching university degree' in Peru. Coaching is learned through professional certifications: ACC Certification (Associate Certified Coach - ICF): 6-9 months (60 hrs training + practice). PCC Certification (Professional Certified Coach - ICF): 12-18 months (125 hrs training + 500 hrs supervised practice). MCC Certification (Master Certified Coach - ICF): 3-5 years (advanced experience + 200 hrs training + 2,500 hrs practice). University Coaching Diplomas: 6-12 months (ESAN, UPC, Pacifico). Ontological Training (Newfield, Axon): 9-12 months. REALITY: You can start paid coaching after 6-12 months of training, but mastery comes with years of practice, supervision, and continuous personal development. Many successful coaches come from previous careers (Psychology, HR, Engineering, Administration) and add coaching as a specialization, not as a first career.

que-tipos-coaching-existen.question: What types of coaching exist?
que-tipos-coaching-existen.answer: The main types of coaching are: 1) EXECUTIVE COACHING - For leaders, managers, C-levels. Focused on leadership, strategic decision-making, team management. 2) CAREER/PROFESSIONAL COACHING - Job transitions, industry change, career development, job search. 3) LIFE COACHING - Purpose, work-life balance, relationships, self-knowledge, integral wellbeing. 4) TECH/TECHNOLOGY COACHING - Specialized in tech professionals: developers, tech leads, product managers. Includes soft skills, tech career path, impostor syndrome. 5) SPORTS COACHING - Athletic performance, competitive mindset, post-injury recovery. 6) TEAM COACHING - Team dynamics, conflict resolution, organizational culture. 7) ONTOLOGICAL COACHING - Based on language, emotions and embodiment. Transformation of the observer you are. 8) HEALTH/WELLNESS COACHING - Healthy habits, fitness, nutrition, wellbeing. Each type requires specific training. I specialize in Tech Coaching + Life Coaching for tech professionals.

cta.title: Didn't find your answer?
cta.subtitle: Contact me directly and I'll resolve all your doubts

SoftSkillsDevelopers.metaTitle: Soft Skills for Developers: Communication, Leadership & Empathy | HugoTech
SoftSkillsDevelopers.metaDescription: Discover the 8 critical Soft Skills every developer needs to grow: communication, collaboration, empathy, adaptability. In 2025, Soft Skills are your competitive advantage against AI.
SoftSkillsDevelopers.title: Soft Skills for Developers
SoftSkillsDevelopers.subtitle: The human skills that AI cannot replace and that determine who advances in their tech career.

definition.title: What are Soft Skills?
definition.content: Soft Skills are the interpersonal, emotional and communication abilities that determine how you work with others, how you adapt to change, and how you solve complex problems in human contexts.
definition.content2: Unlike Hard Skills (programming in Python, using React, knowing AWS), Soft Skills focus on HOW you work, not WHAT you know how to do technically. They are transferable skills to any language, framework or industry.

hiring.title: 85% of hires are based on Soft Skills
hiring.content: According to LinkedIn, 85% of hiring and promotion decisions are based on Soft Skills, not technical skills. You can be a genius in algorithms, but if you don't know how to communicate your ideas, you'll never reach Senior.

senior.title: Differentiator to reach Senior/Lead
senior.content: The difference between a Mid and a Senior is not more complex code: it's mentorship, influence, communication, technical leadership. Soft Skills determine if you scale in your career.

teamwork.title: Tech teams work because of people, not code
teamwork.content: The best teams are not those with the best developers technically, but those that communicate well, trust each other, and resolve conflicts constructively.

impact.title: More impact = Better compensation
impact.content: Developers with solid Soft Skills impact beyond their code: they influence product decisions, lead initiatives, and are references in their teams. That translates into 30-40% higher salaries.

skills.title: The 8 critical Soft Skills for Developers

communication.title: Clear technical communication
communication.content: Being able to explain complex technical concepts to non-technical people (Product Managers, stakeholders, users). Document code clearly. Write descriptive PRs.
communication.example: Instead of saying 'I refactored the authentication module', you explain: 'I separated the token validation logic so it's easier to add OAuth in the future.'

collaboration.title: Collaboration and teamwork
collaboration.content: Work well in pair programming, participate constructively in code reviews, accept feedback without defensiveness, and help other developers grow.
collaboration.example: In a code review, instead of saying 'This code is wrong', you ask: 'Did you consider using X pattern to avoid Y problem? I saw it works well in these cases.'

problemSolving.title: Creative problem solving
problemSolving.content: Think beyond the obvious technical solution. Consider business context, user impact, architecture trade-offs. See the complete problem, not just the code.
problemSolving.example: You propose using a third-party API instead of building a feature from scratch because you reduce development time from 3 months to 2 weeks, even if it's less 'interesting' technically.

adaptability.title: Adaptability and continuous learning
adaptability.content: Ability to learn new technologies quickly, adapt to changes in priorities, and not cling to 'your way' of doing things. Be flexible without losing technical judgment.
adaptability.example: Your team decides to migrate from REST to GraphQL. Instead of resisting, you focus on understanding why GraphQL solves specific problems for your product and learn quickly.

empathy.title: Empathy with users and team
empathy.content: Put yourself in the end user's shoes to design better solutions. Understand the pressures and contexts of your teammates (Product, QA, other developers).
empathy.example: A QA reports a bug that you 'can't reproduce'. Instead of closing it, you schedule a session with them to see how they use the app and discover a real edge case affecting 5% of users.

timeManagement.title: Time management and prioritization
timeManagement.content: Know what to do first, when to say 'no' to tasks that don't add value, estimate realistically, and avoid perfectionism that blocks deliveries.
timeManagement.example: You have 3 tasks: a critical bug, a new feature, and refactoring legacy code. You prioritize the bug because it blocks real users, then the feature, and leave the refactor for a future sprint.

feedback.title: Give and receive constructive feedback
feedback.content: Give technical feedback without attacking the person. Receive criticism without getting defensive. See feedback as an opportunity for growth, not as a personal attack.
feedback.example: You receive a comment on your PR: 'This code is hard to read'. Instead of justifying yourself, you ask: 'What specific part confused you? How would you structure it?'

learning.title: Curiosity and growth mindset
learning.content: Always learning not just technology, but about the business, users, the problem domain. Don't stay in your technical comfort zone.
learning.example: You work at a fintech. Instead of just programming, you learn about banking regulation, how transactions work, and why certain technical decisions are limited by compliance.

Management30.metaTitle: Management 3.0: Agile Leadership for Tech Teams | HugoTech
Management30.metaDescription: Discover Management 3.0: the modern leadership framework for tech teams. Energize people, empowerment, align constraints, develop competencies. In 2025, it's more relevant than ever.
Management30.title: Management 3.0
Management30.subtitle: The modern leadership framework that transforms hierarchical teams into adaptive, creative and self-managed systems.

definition.title: What is Management 3.0?
definition.content: Management 3.0 is a set of games, tools and practices that helps leaders and teams work with an agile and people-centered mindset. It's not a rigid methodology, but a leadership philosophy that recognizes that organizations are complex systems where people matter more than processes.
definition.creator: Created by Jurgen Appelo.
definition.creatorText: Management 3.0 emerges as a response to traditional management models (command-control) and proposes that the best results come from empowered, motivated and purpose-aligned teams.

energize.title: Energize people
energize.content: Happy, motivated and purpose-connected people work better. The leader's role is to create an environment where people feel valued, heard and with autonomy.
energize.practice: Celebrate team achievements, do retrospectives focused on learnings (not blame), and give space for experimentation and creativity.

empower.title: Empower teams
empower.content: Teams must have authority to make decisions without constantly asking permission. The leader doesn't control, facilitates. Autonomy generates commitment.
empower.practice: Use Delegation Poker to define which decisions the team makes without consulting, which require consensus, and which are the leader's.

align.title: Align constraints
align.content: Absolute freedom doesn't work. Teams need clarity on objectives, values, and limits. The leader defines the 'framework' within which the team has autonomy.
align.practice: Define clear OKRs (Objectives & Key Results) so the team knows where they're going, but giving them freedom in HOW to get there.

develop.title: Develop competencies
develop.content: People must constantly grow in technical and soft skills. The leader invests in team development because that multiplies the organization's impact.
develop.practice: Create competency maps, assign time for learning, facilitate internal mentorships, and give continuous feedback.

grow.title: Grow the structure
grow.content: Organizational structure must evolve with the team. Don't cling to rigid hierarchies. Allow roles and responsibilities to change organically according to needs.
grow.practice: Experiment with rotating roles (Scrum Master, retrospective facilitator) or multifunctional squads instead of static departments.

improve.title: Improve continuously
improve.content: Nothing is perfect. The organization must have mechanisms to detect what doesn't work, experiment with changes, and learn quickly from mistakes.
improve.practice: Do periodic retrospectives, measure team well-being metrics (happiness metrics), and do small experiments with clear hypotheses.

delegation.title: Delegation Poker
delegation.content: A game to decide the level of authority in each decision: from 'the leader decides alone' to 'the team decides without consulting'. Clarifies expectations and avoids micromanagement.

kudos.title: Kudo Cards
kudos.content: Physical or digital cards to recognize teammates' achievements. Fosters a culture of appreciation and public recognition of efforts.

okr.title: OKRs (Objectives & Key Results)
okr.content: Framework to align team objectives with organizational ones. Defines WHAT (objective) and HOW we measure success (key results), giving freedom in execution.

competency.title: Competency Matrix
competency.content: Visual map of team competencies: who knows what, at what level, and what they want to learn. Allows identifying gaps and planning development.

LiderazgoIntrovertidos.metaTitle: Leadership for Introverts: Your Introversion is your Superpower | HugoTech
LiderazgoIntrovertidos.metaDescription: Discover why 40% of successful leaders are introverts. Learn to lead from your authenticity: deep listening, strategic thinking, one-on-ones. In 2025, introversion is an advantage.
LiderazgoIntrovertidos.title: Leadership for Introverts
LiderazgoIntrovertidos.subtitle: You don't need to be extroverted to be a great leader. Your introversion can be your greatest strength.

definition.title: What does Leadership for Introverts mean?
definition.content: It's a leadership style that honors the nature of introverted people: deep reflection, active listening, strategic thinking, and one-on-one connections. Introverted leaders don't try to 'fake' being extroverted, but lead from their authenticity.
definition.statText: According to Harvard Business Review studies, 40% of executives and successful leaders are introverts. Includes names like Bill Gates, Larry Page, Mark Zuckerberg, and many CTOs of unicorn startups.

myth1.title: Introverts don't know how to communicate
myth1.content: This is one of the most damaging myths. It's assumed that because introverts prefer small spaces and reflection, they can't communicate ideas effectively.
myth1.reality: Introverts are often excellent communicators when they have time to prepare. They prefer written communication (emails, documents, RFCs) where they can structure ideas clearly. And in meetings, they speak less but with more substance.

myth2.title: Leaders must be charismatic and extroverted
myth2.content: The leader who 'motivates with energy', speaks in public without fear, and 'fills the room' with their presence is idealized. But that's a style, not THE style.
myth2.reality: Leadership is not about being the loudest. Introverted leaders motivate with actions, not with speeches. They empower others instead of being the center of attention. And they generate trust with consistency, not with charisma.

myth3.title: Introverts avoid conflicts
myth3.content: It's assumed that because introverts prefer harmony, they avoid difficult conversations or necessary conflicts.
myth3.reality: Introverts don't avoid conflicts: they approach them with more preparation. They think before speaking, choose their words carefully, and resolve conflicts reflectively instead of impulsively. That usually generates better long-term results.

myth4.title: Introverts can't lead large teams
myth4.content: It's thought that introverts only work in small teams because constant social interactions exhaust them.
myth4.reality: Introverts lead large teams differently: they delegate leadership to others, create clear asynchronous communication structures, and use one-on-ones instead of mass meetings. That usually generates more autonomous and empowered teams.

listening.title: Deep and active listening
listening.content: Introverted leaders listen more than they talk. That allows them to capture problems others ignore, understand unexpressed emotions, and make more informed decisions.

thinking.title: Strategic thinking
thinking.content: Introverts process information deeply before acting. That makes them excellent for complex architectural decisions, long-term planning, and foreseeing risks.

oneOnOne.title: Authentic one-on-one connections
oneOnOne.content: Introverted leaders excel at one-on-ones. They prefer deep conversations with one person than small talk with 20. That generates trust and loyalty in the team.

calm.title: Calm in crisis
calm.content: Introverts don't react impulsively. In crisis moments (production down, team conflict), their reflective nature allows them to stay calm and make rational decisions.

writing.title: Clear written communication
writing.content: Introverts are often better writers than speakers. In the remote tech world of 2025, written communication (Slack, Notion, RFCs) is critical. Introverted leaders shine here.

empower.title: Natural empowerment
empower.content: Introverted leaders don't need to be the center of attention. That makes them excellent at empowering others, giving credit to the team, and creating spaces where others can shine.

meetings.title: Manage your energy in meetings
meetings.tip1: Ask for the agenda in advance to prepare mentally
meetings.tip2: Limit meetings to 25-30 minutes instead of 60 minutes
meetings.tip3: Block time after intense meetings to recharge energy

energy.title: Protect your recharge time
energy.tip1: Block 1-2 hours per day of 'deep work' without interruptions
energy.tip2: Work in asynchronous mode when possible (Slack, Notion)
energy.tip3: Don't feel guilty for saying 'no' to unnecessary meetings

communication.title: Leverage written communication
communication.tip1: Document decisions in RFCs or ADRs (Architecture Decision Records)
communication.tip2: Use Slack threads for structured conversations instead of calls
communication.tip3: Write weekly updates for your team instead of long stand-ups

FeedbackTecnico.metaTitle: Technical Feedback: How to give constructive criticism without breaking egos | HugoTech
FeedbackTecnico.metaDescription: Learn to give technical feedback using the SBI framework. In 2025, feedback focuses on strategic judgment, not syntax. Practical examples for Code Reviews and architecture.
FeedbackTecnico.title: Technical Feedback
FeedbackTecnico.subtitle: The art of giving constructive criticism that accelerates growth without destroying trust.

definition.title: What is Technical Feedback?
definition.content: It's the ability to communicate observations, suggestions or criticism about another person's technical work (code, architecture, design decisions) in a way that the other person receives it as an opportunity for growth, not as a personal attack.
definition.keyText: Effective technical feedback separates observable behavior from the person. You don't say 'You're bad at programming', you say 'This code has X problem that generates Y impact. How can we improve it?'

challenges.title: Why is it difficult to give Technical Feedback?

fear.title: Fear of breaking the relationship
fear.content: You fear the other person will be offended, get defensive, or think you're attacking them. Especially difficult with seniors or close colleagues.

ego.title: Technical ego is fragile
ego.content: Developers associate our identity with our code. Saying 'Your code has problems' feels like saying 'You're not a good developer'. That generates defensiveness.

time.title: Lack of time to explain
time.content: Giving constructive feedback takes time. It's faster to say 'This code is wrong' than to explain WHY it's wrong, WHAT impact it has, and HOW to improve it.

words.title: Not knowing what words to use
words.content: Many of us know WHAT is wrong, but don't know HOW to communicate it without sounding arrogant, condescending or aggressive.

sbi.title: SBI Framework for Technical Feedback
sbi.intro: SBI (Situation-Behavior-Impact) is a framework used in professional coaching that helps you structure feedback clearly, specifically and non-attackingly.

situation.title: Situation (Specific context)
situation.content: Describe WHEN and WHERE the behavior you want to feedback on occurred. Be specific.
situation.exampleText: 'In PR #245 of the payments feature I reviewed yesterday...'

behavior.title: Behavior (Observable and objective)
behavior.content: Describe WHAT the person did in an observable way. Don't interpret intentions. Don't judge. Just describe facts.
behavior.exampleText: '...I saw that the processPayment() method has 250 lines, handles 5 different responsibilities, and doesn't have unit tests.'

impact.title: Impact (Concrete consequences)
impact.content: Explain WHY that's a problem. Connect with real impact: maintainability, bugs, others' time, user experience.
impact.exampleText: 'This makes it very difficult to debug production problems, increases the risk of introducing bugs when modifying it, and makes it hard for other developers to understand the logic. How about we refactor it together into smaller functions?'

code.bad: 'Your code is a mess. Nobody will understand this.'
code.good: 'In yesterday's PR (S), I saw several functions without descriptive names and minimal comments (B). This makes it so when another developer reads this code in 3 months, they'll have to debug it line by line to understand what it does (I). How about we rename the functions and add comments in the more complex parts?'

architecture.bad: 'Why did you use microservices? That's over-engineering.'
architecture.good: 'In the architecture proposal (S), I saw you proposed using microservices for an MVP of 2 features (B). This will increase operational complexity (deploy, monitoring, distributed debugging) when we haven't validated product-market fit yet (I). Did you consider starting with a modular monolith and migrating to microservices only if we scale? We can discuss the trade-offs.'

collaboration.bad: 'You never participate in dailies. You're not a team player.'
collaboration.good: 'In the last 3 dailies (S), I noticed you didn't share blockers or updates (B). This makes the team not know what you're working on or if you need help, which can generate duplication of efforts or avoidable blockers (I). Is there something preventing you from participating? Do you prefer asynchronous updates on Slack?'

OneOnOnes.metaTitle: One-on-Ones: The superpower of technical leadership | HugoTech
OneOnOnes.metaDescription: Learn to have effective One-on-Ones: structure, powerful questions, frequency. In 2025, One-on-Ones are more critical than ever because AI can't have existential conversations.
OneOnOnes.title: One-on-Ones
OneOnOnes.subtitle: The most powerful and underutilized leadership tool in tech teams.

definition.title: What are One-on-Ones?
definition.content: They are regular meetings (usually weekly or biweekly) between a leader and a team member, focused on professional growth, emotional well-being, day-to-day challenges, and expectation alignment. They are NOT status updates of tasks.
definition.keyText: The One-on-One is the collaborator's space, not the leader's. The agenda is defined by the collaborator. The leader is there to listen, support, remove blockers, and help grow.

trust.title: Build deep trust
trust.content: Trust is not generated in team meetings or Slack. It's generated in honest one-on-one conversations where the person feels safe to share doubts, fears, frustrations.

problems.title: Detect problems before they explode
problems.content: Burnout, interpersonal conflicts, lack of role clarity, demotivation. These problems DO NOT appear in dailies. They appear in One-on-Ones when you ask: 'How do you really feel?'

growth.title: Accelerate professional growth
growth.content: It's the space to discuss next career step, performance feedback, skills to develop, and opportunities within the company. Without One-on-Ones, people grow slower or leave.

feedback.title: Safe space for bidirectional feedback
feedback.content: The collaborator can give feedback to the leader about what works and what doesn't in the team. And the leader can give constructive feedback without it feeling like 'public evaluation'.

duration.title: Duration: 30-45 minutes
duration.content: 30 minutes is the minimum. 45 minutes is ideal for deep conversations. Less than 30 minutes feels superficial.

frequency.title: Frequency: Weekly or biweekly
frequency.content: Weekly is ideal for juniors or people new to the team. Biweekly works for seniors with high autonomy. NEVER monthly: loses effectiveness.

agenda.title: Agenda: Defined by the collaborator
agenda.content: The collaborator brings the topics. The leader facilitates. If the collaborator doesn't bring topics, the leader can ask:
agenda.item1: How did you feel this week?
agenda.item3: What do you need help with?
agenda.item4: How are you progressing towards your goals?
agenda.item5: Is there anything you want to learn or improve?

listen.title: Golden rule: Listen 80%, talk 20%
listen.content: The One-on-One is not for the leader to talk. It's for the collaborator to talk and the leader to listen actively, ask deep questions, and help clarify thoughts.

wellbeing.title: Emotional well-being
wellbeing.q1: How have you been feeling lately? (in general, not just at work)
wellbeing.q2: Is there anything keeping you up at night?

growth.title: Professional growth
growth.q1: What do you want to achieve in the next 6 months?
growth.q2: What skill would you like to develop?
growth.q3: Is there a project you'd like to lead?

team.title: Team and collaboration
team.q1: How do you feel working with the team?
team.q2: Is there any conflict or tension I should know about?
team.q3: What could we do better as a team?

feedback.title: Feedback for the leader
feedback.q1: What can I do to help you more?
feedback.q2: Is there anything I do that slows you down or frustrates you?
feedback.q3: How can I improve as a leader?

MetodoHugotech.metaDescription: The only method that integrates technical mentoring, professional coaching, and artificial intelligence to accelerate your growth as a developer or tech lead. 5 proven pillars with +200 developers in Peru.

MetodoHugotech.title: The Hugotech Method

hero.title: Tech Mentoring + AI that Transforms Developers into Leaders
hero.subtitle: The only method in Peru that integrates technical mentoring, professional coaching, and artificial intelligence to accelerate your tech career.

intro.p1: After mentoring over 200 developers, I discovered a pattern: most have the technical knowledge, but lack the strategic guidance to break out of stagnation. It's not lack of talent. It's lack of method.
intro.p2: The Hugotech Method is born from 15+ years in the tech industry, combining my experience as a senior developer, tech lead, and certified professional coach. But what makes it unique in 2025 is that it integrates artificial intelligence not as a replacement, but as a multiplier of your human potential.
intro.p3: This is not a recorded course. Not generic LinkedIn advice. It's a complete system of professional transformation, with 1-on-1 sessions, personalized follow-up, and practical tools you can apply from day one.

problem1.title: Tech's Silent Burnout
problem1.content: I see brilliant developers working 10+ hours daily, learning new frameworks every month, but still feeling stuck. Burnout doesn't scream, it whispers. And by the time you realize it, you've lost years in survival mode.
problem1.impact: This method teaches you to grow without burning out, to say no without guilt, and to lead projects without sacrificing your mental health.

problem2.title: AI Anxiety (2025)
problem2.content: ChatGPT, GitHub Copilot, Cursor... AI is writing code faster than us. It's normal to feel afraid. But fear paralyzes. Strategy propels.
problem2.impact: This method positions you as the human that AI cannot replace: the one who makes critical decisions, leads teams, and solves ambiguous problems that machines don't understand.

problem3.title: Chronic Impostor Syndrome
problem3.content: You're senior on paper but feel like you'll be exposed any moment. You avoid applying for senior roles, reject leadership opportunities, and self-sabotage by comparing yourself to Twitter's 'geniuses'.
problem3.impact: This method gives you the tools to recognize your true value, communicate it confidently, and advance without asking permission.

pillars.title: The 5 Pillars of the Hugotech Method
pillars.subtitle: These pillars are the result of years of mentoring developers at all levels. This isn't theory. It's what works in the reality of Latin American tech in 2025.

pillar1.title: Professional Identity Clarity
pillar1.content: You can't get where you want if you don't know who you are today. This pillar helps you define your identity beyond job titles: Are you the critical problem solver? The scalable systems architect? The leader who empowers teams? Your identity defines the opportunities you attract.
pillar1.practice1: Self-awareness session: we identify your unique strengths (technical + human)
pillar1.practice2: Positioning exercise: we create your 'value proposition' in one sentence
pillar1.practice3: Career map: we chart the path from where you are to where you want to be
pillar1.quote: Result: You'll know exactly what to say when asked 'tell me about yourself' in interviews or networking.

pillar2.title: Personalized Technical Mentoring
pillar2.content: Every developer has different gaps. One needs to deepen architecture. Another needs to improve code reviews. Another needs to learn to communicate technical decisions to non-tech stakeholders. This pillar is 1-on-1 mentoring focused on YOUR specific needs, not a generic syllabus.
pillar2.practice1: Live code review: we analyze your code together (not from criticism, from learning)
pillar2.practice2: Technical interview simulations: we practice system design, algorithms, and behavioral questions
pillar2.practice3: Curated resource library: I share only what you need to read/watch, not 100 random links
pillar2.quote: Result: You go from 'I can do this' to 'I can explain why I do it this way and when not to do it'.

pillar3.title: Soft Skills that Accelerate (not Decorate)
pillar3.content: Soft skills aren't 'nice to have'. They're the differentiator between a senior developer and a tech lead. Between someone who resolves tickets and someone who influences strategy. This pillar teaches you to communicate with impact, give constructive feedback, lead without formal authority, and negotiate your salary without fear.
pillar3.practice1: Role-playing difficult conversations: we practice how to give feedback to a toxic colleague, how to say no to your boss, how to ask for a raise
pillar3.practice2: Communication framework: you learn SBI (Situation-Behavior-Impact) to give feedback without generating conflict
pillar3.practice3: Effective one-on-ones: if you lead a team, I teach you how to run 1-on-1 meetings that really matter
pillar3.quote: Result: You go from 'the quiet dev' to 'the dev everyone listens to when speaking'.

pillar4.title: Artificial Intelligence as an Ally
pillar4.content: In 2025, not knowing how to use AI is like not knowing how to use Google in 2010. This pillar isn't about 'learning to use ChatGPT' (you already know that). It's about how AI powers your learning process, debugging, architecture, and even your career plan. I teach you to be the human that AI complements, not the one it replaces.
pillar4.practice1: Strategic prompting: you learn to ask questions that save you hours of research
pillar4.practice2: AI as co-mentor: we use AI to generate case studies, simulate interviews, and create practice exercises adapted to your level
pillar4.practice3: Anti-replacement positioning: we identify which of your skills are irreplaceable by AI (spoiler: there are more than you think)
pillar4.quote: Result: AI becomes your productivity tool, not your source of anxiety.

pillar5.title: Accountability and Continuous Follow-up
pillar5.content: Mentoring without follow-up is like going to the gym once a year. This pillar ensures that you don't just receive information, but APPLY IT. Recurring sessions, specific tasks between sessions, and a tracking system to measure your real progress (not just feelings).
pillar5.practice1: Biweekly or weekly sessions (depending on your plan): I don't abandon you after a motivational talk
pillar5.practice2: Actionable tasks: each session ends with 3 concrete actions for the next week
pillar5.practice3: Progress dashboard: we measure quantifiable advances (salary, role level, projects led, interviews passed)
pillar5.quote: Result: In 3-6 months you see real changes, not just 'I learned a lot'.

diff1.title: It's Not Just Technical Mentoring
diff1.content: I combine technical mentoring (architecture, code, best practices) with professional coaching (identity, purpose, leadership). You see results in your code AND your career.

diff2.title: Adapted to Latin American Context
diff2.content: This isn't translated US mentoring. It understands the reality of working in Peruvian companies, regional startups, or remote companies from Latin America. We speak the same language (literally and figuratively).

diff3.title: Integrates AI Without Hype
diff3.content: I don't sell you AI as a magic solution. I teach you to use it strategically to be more efficient, without losing your human essence. AI is a tool, not a replacement.

diff4.title: Measurable Results
diff4.content: We don't measure 'satisfaction'. We measure salary increases, promotions achieved, interviews passed, projects led, work hours reduced without losing impact. Facts, not words.

process.title: How Does the Process Work?
process.subtitle: The method is implemented in 3 phases, each with clear and measurable objectives:

phase1.title: Diagnosis and Alignment (2-3 weeks)
phase1.content: Before moving forward, we need clarity. In this phase we identify:
phase1.item1: Where you are today: technical level, soft skills, employment situation, emotional state
phase1.item2: Where you want to be: specific goal (e.g., 'get senior role in 6 months', 'lead team at current company')
phase1.item3: What's holding you back: limiting beliefs, technical gaps, lack of strategy

phase2.title: Active Transformation (2-4 months)
phase2.content: This is where the deep work happens. Recurring sessions where:
phase2.item1: We work on your technical gaps with practical mentoring (code reviews, architecture, interviews)
phase2.item2: We develop your soft skills with simulations and proven frameworks
phase2.item3: We apply AI to accelerate your learning and productivity

phase3.title: Consolidation and Autonomy (1-2 months)
phase3.content: I don't make you dependent. I prepare you to fly solo. In this phase:
phase3.item1: You reduce session frequency (from weekly to biweekly to monthly)
phase3.item2: You apply what you've learned in real projects with my remote support
phase3.item3: You create your own continuous growth system post-mentoring

profile1.title: Stuck Mid-Level Developers
profile1.description: You have 2-5 years of experience. You resolve tickets, work on features, but don't see how to make the jump to senior. You lack clarity on what to learn, how to demonstrate your value, and how to position yourself for a promotion.
profile1.result: In 4-6 months, you have the technical skills and confidence to apply for senior roles (internally or externally) and pass the interviews.

profile2.title: Seniors Who Want to Lead (Without Dying in the Process)
profile2.description: You're technically senior, but leading a team gives you vertigo. You worry about not knowing how to give feedback, manage conflicts, or losing time in meetings. You want to be a tech lead without sacrificing your mental health.
profile2.result: In 3-4 months, you lead your first team confidently, applying proven leadership frameworks (Management 3.0, effective one-on-ones, constructive feedback).

profile3.title: Burned Out Tech Leads
profile3.description: You already lead a team, but feel the weight of the world is on your shoulders. You work 10+ hours, don't delegate well, and burnout is knocking at your door. You need a method to lead without burning out.
profile3.result: In 2-3 months, you reduce your work hours by 30%, delegate effectively, and recover the enjoyment of your role (yes, it's possible).

ia2025.title: Why This Method Is Critical in the AI Era
ia2025.intro: Artificial intelligence is not going to replace all developers. But it will replace those who don't adapt. This method prepares you to be irreplaceable.

reason1.title: AI Writes Code, You Make Decisions
reason1.content: ChatGPT can generate a REST API in seconds. But it doesn't know if your startup needs that architecture or if it's overkill. It doesn't understand business context, your team's constraints, or the cost of maintaining that code 3 years later. You do. This method trains you in critical thinking, architectural decisions, and professional judgment. Things that AI (yet) doesn't do.

reason2.title: Soft Skills Are Your Competitive Advantage
reason2.content: AI can write a pull request. It can't resolve a conflict between two senior devs. It can't motivate a demotivated junior. It can't negotiate budget with stakeholders. The soft skills many ignore today are the most valuable skills of 2025. This method prioritizes them.

reason3.title: Learning to Learn Is the Meta-Skill
reason3.content: Frameworks change every 2 years. AI evolves every 3 months. The only constant is change. This method doesn't teach you 'what to learn'. It teaches you 'how to learn anything fast', using AI as an accelerated learning tool. You develop the ability to adapt to whatever comes.

conclusion.title: In summary:
conclusion.content: AI is a tool. You are the craftsman. This method turns you into the craftsman that AI powers, not the craftsman that AI replaces.

items.question: Why Hugo Casanova and not another tech coach?
items.answer: Because Hugo LIVED 18 years in tech from 'doing': Backend Developer, Tech Lead, Country Manager. He reached visible success... and internal emptiness. His breaking point led him to ontological coaching (ICF training), where he discovered he DIDN'T need to 'do things better'. He needed to ReCode himself as BEING. That's how his Ontological ReCode¬Æ method was born: as engineer you recode buggy code, as leader you ReCode limiting beliefs, reactive emotionality, and toxic leadership patterns. He's the ONLY coach who unites senior engineering with Ontological ReCoding in Latin America.

items.question: What exactly is Ontological ReCoding¬Æ?
items.answer: It's NOT 'improve your leadership skills'. It's NOT 'learn to communicate better'. Ontological coaching works on WHO YOU ARE when you lead, communicate, decide. Your OBSERVER: how you see yourself, your team, challenges. Your LANGUAGE: what you say creates your reality. Your EMOTIONALITY: you can't 'act calm' if inside you're anxious. ReCode¬Æ Method: as engineer you recode buggy code (if-else, loops, architecture). As leader, you ReCode your identity, your conversations, your emotional patterns. Same logic: identify bug (limiting belief), understand root cause (where it comes from), recode (transform observer), test (new results). It's ontological coaching with engineering thinking.

items.question: How is it different from traditional executive coaching?
items.answer: Traditional coaching: 'What do you want to achieve?' ‚Üí actions ‚Üí habits. Ontological coaching: 'WHO are you BEING when you lead?' ‚Üí observer transformation ‚Üí identity shift ‚Üí actions flow naturally. Example: Traditional coach: 'Learn to delegate (technique)'. Ontological ReCode¬Æ: 'Why do you need to control everything? What do you fear if you let go? Who would you BE if you trusted?' You don't learn to delegate. You BECOME someone who naturally trusts. Delegation is consequence, not objective. Plus: Hugo speaks your language (sprints, deploys, on-call, tech debt). He doesn't have to 'understand your context' because he lived it 18 years.

items.question: What's the ReCode¬Æ Fulldays and Camps format?
items.answer: ReCode¬Æ Fulldays: intensive 1-day immersions (8 hours) where we work deeply on ONE specific transformation: from control to trust, from impostor to leader, from burnout to sustainable energy. It's NOT theory. It's experiential ontological work with powerful questions, somatic practices, identity deconstruction. You leave with deep shift, not just 'notes'. ReCode¬Æ Camps: 2-3 day retreats (fri-sun) for teams or individual leaders seeking profound transformation. We combine ontological coaching, nature, vulnerability, real community. Participants describe it as 'before and after in my leadership'. Investment: fulldays from $500, camps from $1,500. First exploratory session always free.

items.question: Is it for me if I don't have a 'big problem'?
items.answer: Ontological ReCode¬Æ is NOT therapy (doesn't work on trauma). It's NOT consulting (doesn't give you solutions). It's accompaniment for leaders who: (1) Feel 'successful outside, empty inside'. (2) Want to lead from purpose, not obligation. (3) Seek sustainable high performance, not burnout. (4) Want authentic relationships, not masks. (5) Want to BE the leader they admire, not act like one. If you're 'fine but not fulfilled', if you sense 'there must be another way to lead', if you're tired of 'acting confident' when inside you doubt: ReCode¬Æ is for you. It's not about fixing problems. It's about expanding who you ARE.

items.question: How long until I see results?
items.answer: FIRST SESSION: you leave with deep clarity (not 'aha' moments, but ontological shifts). 3 MONTHS (12 sessions): sustainable identity transformation. You stop 'trying to be better leader' and start BEING different leader naturally. 6 MONTHS: consolidated ReCode¬Æ. Your team, peers, family notice you're different (calmer, clearer, more present, more powerful). It's NOT 'learning techniques gradually'. Ontological coaching can generate immediate shifts ('I never saw it that way'). But consolidating new identity requires time, practice, accompaniment. First session is free: you'll know if ReCode¬Æ resonates with you. No pressure, no sales. Just authentic conversation.

items.question: Do you work 1-on-1 or with teams?
items.answer: BOTH. (1) Individual Ontological Coaching: for CTOs, Tech Leads, Engineering Managers, Staff Engineers who need profound personal transformation. 1-hour sessions, biweekly, 3-6 month minimum. (2) Team ReCode¬Æ Programs: for 5-15 person teams needing culture, collaboration, leadership transformation. 12-week programs with group + individual sessions. (3) ReCode¬Æ Fulldays and Camps: intensive for individuals or teams seeking deep transformation in short time. First call is diagnostic: we see what format fits your real need.

items.answer: Yes, 100% remote. I serve clients throughout Latin America (Mexico, Colombia, Argentina, Chile) and United States. Sessions via Zoom/Google Meet, Spanish or English. Flexible schedule for your timezone. Ontological coaching has no borders: if your challenge is leadership, identity, purpose, I can accompany you wherever you are. ReCode¬Æ Fulldays and Camps can be in-person (Peru/your country) or remote intensive format.

ReCode¬Æ Fulldays: from $500 (individual), $3,000 (team 5-10 people). ReCode¬Æ Camps: from $1,500 (individual 2 days), $8,000 (team retreat 3 days).
